title: we dont owe musical genius to the eu
story: Fine, highfalutin words, Bono.But try telling them to the ­millions of young people who are unemployed in Italy, Spain and Greece, the economies of those proud countries dragged down by the dead weight of the euro. And try out the windbag oratory on the .million decent British democrats who voted to leave the European Union, and who have been told ever since that they are racist, ignorant ­bigots who should never be allowed near a polling booth.I like Bono. In person, he is a decent, thoughtful man. His band are not bad. But why do the former rebels of rock music always tug their forelocks to the European Union  Why does everyone in leather trousers act like the EU is an unalloyed good thing  Why does rock music have a blind spot when it comes to Brussels How can Bono, right, possibly mistake Jean-Claude Juncker for Joe Strummer   The EU is the ESTABLISHMENT, man! And the EU is the ­establishment at its most ­unaccountable, undemocratic, incompetent and corrupt.The EU is not a beautul thing, Bono. It is a crumbling ­expansionist empire, rotten to the core, merciless in its opposition to democracy.The EU is a gravy train, Bono, a trough for puffed-up political piggies, a sclerotic body of ­privileged old white men in suits with MEPs who do not have to provide receipts for their £,-a-month expenses. The EU really stinks, Bono.And the music that you and I grew up with — the music we loved, the music U and I were inspired by, the music we placed at the centre of our worlds — was meant to be against this kind of thing. Bono bent the knee to the bullies of Brussels in the same week that Bob Geldof sent a ­letter to Theresa May warning her that Brexit will be the day the music dies.“Imagine Britain without its music,” thundered Geldof’s letter, co-signed by musicians including Sting, Ed Sheeran, Jarvis Cocker and Damon Albarn. “If it’s hard for us, then it’s impossible for the rest of the world. Britain does rule the waves. The airwaves. But Brexit threatens, as it does so much , this vast voice.”But it is simply not true that our country owes its musical genius to the European Union. The golden years of British music were before we joined the EU — when it was still being touted to us as a common market — back in .The Beatles, the Rolling Stones, The Who, The Kinks, Pink Floyd and Led Zeppelin all somehow managed to make great music without Brussels. Now Geldof and his co-signatories seriously suggest that British music can’t survive outside the European Union.No doubt the Brexit-loathing Boomtown Rat believes this rubbish but everyone  who signed his Whinge Aid letter should have paused to think before signing. Because by claiming that Brexit will kill British music, Ed Sheeran, Sting and the rest just make themselves look like laughably out-of-touch luvvies. Not a good look for the wild boys of rock ’n’ roll.Geldof is right about one thing — British music has been brilliant for  years because our little country embraced the world.But John Lennon, Jimmy Page, Joe Strummer, Mick Jones, Ray Davies, Robert Plant, Mick Jagger, Keith Richards, Eric Clapton and Pete Townshend opened their ears and their hearts to the sounds coming out of America.The glorious music that smashed down the walls between white music and black music was born in Chicago and Nashville and Detroit and Memphis.  Its roots were in the backwoods of the Deep South and the ­Mississippi Delta, and reached all the way back to Africa. Belgium never came into it, Bob.The Rolling Stones never needed a grant from the EU. They just needed one glimpse of Buddy Holly, one listen to Muddy Waters, one nod from Elvis Presley. British bands changed the world and they sure as hell did it without the help of the European Union. Sorry, Bob. Sorry, Bono. But no British musician in history was ever inspired by the mysterious rhythms coming out of Brussels.PETER JACKSON’S new film, They Shall Not Grow Old, shows painstakingly coloured images from World War One for the very first time.Because we have only experienced World War One in black and white footage and photos, there has always felt like a huge distance between our time and the unimaginable horrors of the trenches.Lord Of The Rings director Jackson has bridged that gap and the results, above, take your breath away. He says: “The war was a colour war. You’re seeing it as they saw it. And they saw it in colour.”World War One never felt closer. And the humour, humanity and courage of the men who fought it has never been more heartbreaking.BEST wishes for the future to Trevor Engelson and his bride Tracey Kurland, who were married in a low-key ceremony in Calornia last weekend.Andyou don’t recognise the names, that is because Mr Engelson has chosen to keep a discreet silence on the subject of his two-year marriage to Meghan Markle.And in an age where every broken relationship is ­dissected on social media, isn’t it refreshing to see a man who can keep a dignied silence “WE lost the match but won the battle,” claimed Conor McGregor after his beating in last weekend’s UFC .  What planet was that victory on then, Conor To the casual fan it looked like McGregor  followed up months of denigrating Khabib Nurmagomedov with a feeble performance in the octagon and a lack of grace in defeat.True, Khabib spoilt his victory by jumping into the crowd to continue the punch-up with McGregor’s corner.  But for the le of me I can’t see how Conor McGregor can claim anything other than unconditional surrender. Neither man brought credit to MMA.There is only one reason why mainstream sports fans have been paying interest to Mixed Martial Arts in recent years and that is Conor McGregor. But after the squalid scenes around Conor v Khabib, many of us will be turning off the MMA.Even Mike Tyson was shocked. And he once bit off part of a man’s ear.WHAT my mum would have found unforgivable about Strictly star Seann Walsh snogging Katya Jones is that it happened when Walsh’s girlfriend, Rebecca Humphries, was home alone on her BIRTHDAY.My mum would never have forgiven that kind of casual cruelty from some curly-haired love rat. And I suspect the great British public will feel the same. But what we call the Strictly curse is really just an office romance that spirals out of control.People get thrown together at work all the time. The dference is that a couple from the accounts department don’t usually spend hours every day rubbing up against each other perfecting their Paso Doble.But the intense, intimate physical contact of doing Strictly makes it certain the curse will strike again.The mystery is why Katya was never led astray by Ed Balls.FEMALE terrorist, married to a British jihadi, claimed a council breached her human rights by not giving her a new home after she turned down seven homes because they were not big enough or not in the right location.Kindly Brent Council also offered her £, to put down a deposit on a home of her own.Are we insane Our welfare state was built to care for the most vulnerable members of our society.Not creatures who would spit on our society’s grave.TINA TURNER is the only female performer who was hotter live than Blondie’s Debbie Harry in her pouting, heavy-lidded prime.So it comes as some surprise to hear Tina say that she never tried to be sexy on stage. “Fishnets are practical,” Tina says primly. “They don’t run. And leather doesn’t show the perspiration on stage or wrinkle. I only wore a mini-dress because everyone knows you can’t dance in a dress that goes past your knee.”OK, Tina, we believe you – even though your practical work clothes launched a million adolescent fantasies. And that was just in my house.DRESSED like a street-walking disco ball, Taylor Swt urges America to go out and vote Democrat in the American mid-term elections.I admire young Taylor but does it never occur to these celebrities that their smug self-importance might possibly be drumming up votes for the other side But where were your sensible shoes WHY should anyone vote Conservative  This Government is slashing benefits for the British poor and disabled but can still find £billion in foreign aid money to improve roads and railways in Pakistan and India. Why should we vote for you, Theresa There is nothing remotely Conservative about you.WHY should anyone vote Conservative  This Government is slashing benefits for the British poor and disabled but can still find £billion in foreign aid money to improve roads and railways in Pakistan and India.Why should we vote for you, Theresa There is nothing remotely Conservative about you.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: men stop chatting up schoolgirls
story: The figures come from a report by children’s charity Plan International UK, which also found two-thirds of girls say they have experienced unwanted sexual attention in public.A third of girls have been touched, groped or grabbed by men they don’t know. This kind of thing is so commonplace that many — some as young as eight — feel street harassment is “part of growing up”. How awful is that  Partly, the problem is that somewhere along the line, the idea that schoolgirls are “sexy” has become normalised, acceptable, even mainstream.Yes, I know that the waters were somewhat muddied by the likes of Britney Spears in her Baby One More Time video and Gemma Arterton in her St Trinian’s films — both looking as sexy as heck in school unorm.  And yes, I know a lot of girls look older than they are, and might even try to do so by wearing make-up, smoking or shortening their skirts on the way to and from school.But let’s be really clear about this. — girls young enough to wear school unorm are children. And the idea of any man thinking it’s OK to wolf-whistle, chat up or give any kind of sexual attention to a girl in a unorm is not just seriously worrying. It should be a criminal offence.By the way, I wonder what a similar survey of boys would find. Because the thought of women wolf-whistling schoolboys in the street is unimaginable, right  Parents of ­secondary school children need to give them some freedom to help them on the path to adulthood.Often, that involves letting them walk unaccompanied to school.  But the idea that doing that is exposing their child to the possibility of sexual harassment will be pretty distressing to any parent.One of the saddest things about this report is how many of the girls interviewed thought this kind of behaviour is “normal”. One -year-old said she felt street harassment was part of the “bro culture” and her dad had told her: “You know what men are like.”  What kind of advice is that for your daughter Another girl, aged , said: “It’s just become normal.” But the net result of behaviour like this is that it makes girls scared of walking the streets.All too often, our response to such news is to try to protect girls by telling them not to look too ­provocative. But that just perpetuates the idea men “can’t help themselves” so it’s down to the girls, and the way they dress, to make sure they are left alone.You can’t blame girls or women for men’s behaviour, no matter what theof their skirt. But the dficult truth is that we know women do have to ­mody their behaviour, and the way they dress, to stop men from ­commenting on their appearance, harassing them or worse.Perhaps what I am most shocked about is the young age at which this starts. One good thing is that these days, girls at secondary school have phones. They can record things that happen to them and report it. Also, Plan International UK is calling on bystanders to challenge harassment when they see it.Certainly,I was around someone wolf-whistling schoolgirls, I’d flip my lid. I would not be too scared to speak my mind and verbally intervene. I think my opening ­gambit would be: “How would you feelthat were your sister, ­granddaughter or daughter some old git was harassing ”To any man reading this who thinks it’s OK to talk to schoolgirls like this, let me tell you some of these girls are terried. It’s not funny or cute. It’s threatening. Lots of teen girls look older than they are butyou are confused and in doubt, here is a clue: The school unorm is a giveaway.Any man who leers at a child in a unorm is nothing short of ­disturbed. Andthey can’t stop themselves from doing so, the law needs to intervene.AS you know, I’m a huge advocate of body acceptance and self-love but I confess to a moment of envy at model Rachel McCord’s fantastic figure.Yes, clearly she must spend most of each day at the gym . . . But you have to give credit where credit is due. And she looks amazing!ANOTHER day, another crazy promise from Labour. This time it was Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell saying a Labour government would bring in a four-day working week.This, as Treasury analysis shows, means Labour would have to borrow £trillion to bankroll its spending spree over the next ten years – the equivalent of £, for every UK household. Frankly,the Labour Party gets into power, it will end up being a zero-day week as business will collapse and there will be no jobs to go to. The simple fact is you can’t run a country or a business on a four-day week.I LOVE a good party as much as the next person.But I can’t be the only person who rolled my eyes at the claim that Coldplay frontman Chris Martin and actress Dakota Johnson hosted a “baby gender reveal party” on Sunday.Apparently, large arches of pink and blue balloons were spotted flying above a star- studded bash at Martin’s Malibu home. Moments later, blue balloons were freed into the air, presumably announcing a baby boy is on the way.The couple claim it was just her birthday party but the singer did help introduce us to the term “conscious uncoupling”. Stand by for this being a new thing . . .She was being “punished” for running away with her Hindu boyfriend.Police were reportedly called to the scene but did not make any arrests – which beggars belief, doesn’t it Stories like this are a reminder that religion can be a negative power as well as a positive.I COULDN’T agree more with Sir Anthony Seldon, above, Buckingham University’s vice-chancellor, who wants the uni to adopt an actively anti-drugs stance.My son is at Buckingham uni and they already have snfer dogs all around campus, randomly checking students. Sir Anthony says he wants to create a “psychological contract” between students and the university so undergraduates implicitly agree to shun drugs when they enrol, which I think is a brilliant idea.His approach is the opposite to Sheffield University, where the student union gave advice on how to take ious hard drugs safely. But the fact is drugs aren’t safe and they ruin lives.  Barely a week goes by without another drug death appearing in the news.Some might say a drug-free campus is unrealistic. And sure, you probably can’t stop everyone taking them.  Nor can you prevent people wanting to experiment.  But making young people really aware that drugs are not only dangerous but illegal can only be a good thing.A WRITER called Kamin Mohammadi had an Instagram rant about “manspreading” this week. And yes, I know this happens. But I think we’ve got to get better at politely asking people to just stop it.Forget gender for a moment. I think it comes down to respect: It’s just blatantly rude to invade someone ’s space and the answer, in my view, is to call the person out.  If someone’s arm is on my arm rest on a train or plane, I ask them – in the nicest possible way – to move it.Let’s not be embarrassed when it’s someone’s legs.My personal bugbear is backpacks. I called a man out for keeping his on while on a crowded Tube train this week and he was really apologetic.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pm must secure free trade deal
story: As the Prime Minister heads into the most signicant EU summit, she must secure the Brexit promised to the ­British public.Now is the time to deliver for the United Kingdom on the Conservatives’  General Election manesto promise to take back control of our laws, borders, money and trade.It does not get clearer than the pledge: “We will no longer be members of the single market or customs union.”  Our manesto also promised that our laws would be made in the UK and interpreted by judges here, not in Europe. That’s why the Prime Minister’s Chequers proposal was not right.Under such a deal, we would be required to follow EU laws under the EU rule book and we would still be subject to the European Court of Justice.We would be out of Europe, yet still run by Europe. Any proposal that is brought forward and put to Parliament needs to take back control of our laws and make sure the European Court has no say over us.  So what should Theresa May do  The answer, once again, is set out clearly in the  Conservative manesto.It says: “We will seek a deep and special partnership including a comprehensive free-trade and customs agreement.”  That’s why the Prime Minister should move on from her Chequers proposal and seek an advanced free-trade deal with the EU. A comprehensive free-trade deal, like the EU’s free-trade deals with Canada and Japan, is what our manesto promises require.Such a deal would ensure we take back control of our laws, borders, money and trade. It would honour the referendum mandate. It would be in line with our manesto commitments. And it would work for the EU too. The Government’s objection to this is the supposed dficulty of keeping an open border in Northern Ireland.For this reason, Government figures claim we cannot seek a trade deal with the EU unless this problem is solved. This is nonsense.Clear proposals have been set out by two former Northern Ireland Secretaries as to how a frictionless border can be maintained under a free-trade agreement. These proposals have been endorsed by former Brexit Secretary David Davis and Good Friday Agreement architect Lord Trimble.Moreover, former Cabinet minister Iain Duncan Smith has set out how we can build on the system of joint border controls at Dover to avoid delays or friction at the UK’s borders — including in Ireland. This would work for the EU’s rules and ensure a positive future relationship going forward.This approach is not simply a bad use of taxpayers’ money. It breaks another manesto pledge.For our  manesto says “it is necessary to agree the terms of our future partnership alongside our withdrawal, reaching agreement on both within two years” of our serving notice to leave the EU. In other words, by the end of March next year.So it is wrong for the Government to agree withdrawal terms without sorting out the full detail of our future relationship. A temporary fix does not honour the referendum mandate, it does not keep our manesto promise and it certainly fails to look after our hard-earned money.Moreover, would this temporary fix really be temporary  Just ask the people of Norway how such a deal turned out for them. In  they signed the European Economic Area Agreement. They were told by the EU their sovereignty would be respected. Yet  years later, this “temporary” arrangement has become permanent.Meanwhile, the cost has increased ten-fold and nearly , EU directives and regulations have been implemented through Norway’s EEA agreement.Our Government should fear to tread such a dangerous path. Voters will not tolerate any “temporary” arrangement becoming permanent. They would see it as a betrayal. People voted to leave the EU because they wanted change. They believed in Britain and the land of opportunity we can build. They voted to take back control of our laws, money, borders and trade.The Conservative manesto promised that we would leave the EU altogether. That we would seek a free-trade deal and a new national future.Now is the time for the Government to honour the referendum mandate and the Conservative manesto by seeking a free­-trade deal with the EU that enables Britain to become an economic powerhouse in the decades to come.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit is worst defeat since 1066
story: As negotiations flicker to a halt, it seems Brexit actually means abject surrender, taking orders from Brussels and standing mute as the Council of Europe assumes control of our economy. We risk being sold down the river.Barring a last-minute revolt by Tory Brexiteers, Brussels has won and we have lost. The world’s sixth-largest economy will not just be worse off outside the EU, but reduced to a powerless political pawn on its margins — and paying for it.Sniggering can be heard across the capitals of Europe, with France guffawing loudest. The British Lion is a toothless kitten and we are the laughing stock of Europe.Unless stopped by her Cabinet, her MPs or by Parliament itself, this Prime Minister seems to be leading us to the greatest defeat since the Norman Conquest in , the last time we capitulated to a foreign power.The ransom demanded for our degrading humiliation — £BILLION of taxpayers’ money — is merely a down payment. The botched Chequers deal will bind this country in subordination to Europe.Forget about becoming a sovereign, free-trading nation. We will accept EU rules indefinitely while having no say at all in their terms or conditions. In effect, our economy will be run by Brussels, not by our democratically elected government.For an example of missed opportunities and failed leadership, this beats even last year’s election disaster, which wasted the first Tory majority for  years and put Marxist Labour within grasp of power.Worse, it now seems the PM’s apparent last-ditch capitulation was stitched up months ago behind closed doors after a dodgy threat by car giants to leave the UK.Now the Tory party is in uproar, with cries for a leadership contest. Downing Street is stupidly threatening a snap election. Nobody buys that except Jeremy Corbyn, who is licking his lips at the scent of power. Ministers, like frogs in a pot, are sizing up whether to jump or stew. Careers will be made or broken.At least three — and maybe six — are threatening to quit at tomorrow’s Cabinet unless Theresa blinks. Tory MPs are close to triggering a leadership fight, with sketchy plans for a quick and ruthless contest. “We have the numbers,” says one Tory MP.“If anything the mood is hardening, not softening.”Ex-Brexit secretary David Davis, the first rebel to quit Cabinet, will certainly run, infuriating Boris Johnson, who thinks it should be him. title: this is your brexit boudicca moment theresa its time to say on your way barnier like up yours delors
story: I could see where he was going with this. After all, as we remember from school, this ancient British queen rose up against the Roman Empire, winning battles, slaughtering enemies and forcing the Romans to contemplate leaving Britain all together.“But, hang on,” I replied. “Wasn’t Boudicca eventually defeated ”Whatever the details, my friend was right. It is time for Theresa May to call on her deepest reserves of defiance and stand up to the European Union.Brussels has rejected her Brexit proposals, insulted us at the recent Salzburg summit and wants to dismember the United Kingdom by effectively annexing Northern Ireland for itself.Theresa May’s respect towards the EU has been met consistently with contempt for Britain. She has wished Brussels every success, while they wish us nothing but failure and decline. She has suggested solutions while they point out problems. And she has taken her Government to the brink by proposing a future relationship that is hated by many of her own MPs and supporters.It is time, now, to stop.Her Chequers plan already goes too far. It would tie us to European laws, over which we would have no say, and force us to accept the rulings of the European Court of Justice.It would prevent us from taking our own decisions and making our economy more competitive. And it almost certainly stops us from striking our own trade deals.Worse still,the Government persists with Chequers, we will end up with something even worse: Chequers Minus, which could mean making annual payments to Brussels, complying with more EU laws and accepting liberal immigration rules that amount to continued free movement.The longer we pretend Chequers can survive, the worse the outcome will be. As we negotiate the Withdrawal Agreement, Britain should be seeking watertight assurances about our future relationship. Without them, we will sign away a £billion orce payment without any confidence we will get a fair deal for the future.But the crisis the Prime Minister described to Parliament yesterday, and which the Cabinet will discuss today, is not about Chequers, but the so-called “backstop” — what should happen to Northern Irelandthere is no eventual agreement on the future relationship.The EU’s proposition is an outrage. If there is no deal on the future relationship, they expect Northern Ireland to remain inside the Customs Union and, in effect, the single market.That would mean, in trying to avoid a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic, we would create a hard border between Northern Ireland and Great Britain. That’s right, a border within our own country to avoid having one with another.The backstop would mean politicians in the Republic have a say over laws in Northern Ireland, while politicians in Belfast and London would have none. And it effectively breaches the Good Friday Agreement, which demands that Northern Ireland’s place in the United Kingdom is respected unless a majority of Northern Irish people vote for the reunication of Ireland.The one concession the EU seems willing to make is that the whole of the United Kingdom can remain inside the Customs Union, not just Northern Ireland.But it insists there can be no time limit, and no right for the UK to unilaterally withdraw from the backstop.In other words, we would be trapped inside the Customs Union — following laws over which we have no say, letting Brussels grant trading access to our market for other countries and leaving us unable to agree trade deals of our own — for ever.This, of course, has always been the EU’s game. They have cynically used the Northern Irish peace process to try to tie the whole of the United Kingdom to the EU’s rules and regulations. And in their naivety, our negotiators have walked straight into the trap.The PM needs to tell the EU to get stuffed. And she must go back to the drawing board. She must replace Chequers with an ambitious, Canada Plus, free trade agreement between the UK and the EU. She must insist that the Northern Irish solution lies with technology and policy that avoid checks at the border. And she must tear up the backstop.One alternative, still a compromise for Brexiteers like me, is to agree that the UK will remain inside the Customs Union for a period of up to five years while the appropriate systems are put into place.Critics will say the EU will never agree. Butthey cannot accept a trade deal consistent with their principles and which respects the integrity of their single market, we know they seek only a damaging deal for Britain, or no deal at all.Others will say the Government could not get this kind of plan through the Commons. But it stands a better chance than Chequers Minus.This was, in fact, the plan Theresa May first set out at Lancaster House in January .There, she warned against a Chequers-style deal, saying: “We do not seek to hold on to bits of membership as we leave” and “we will not have truly leftwe are not in control of our own laws”.And she warned against what the backstop demands. She insisted on creating “no new barriers to living and doing business within our own Union”, and warned against “an unlimited transitional status”, which she called a “kind of permanent political purgatory”.Instead, she sought “a comprehensive free trade agreement” and the freedom for “Britain to negotiate its own trade agreements” with other countries.In other words, she described the Canada Plus agreement that is prepared and drafted but gathering dust inside the Brexit Department.Many years ago, The Sun advised us to say “up yours, Delors” to a meddling European Commissioner. Today, the PM needs to find her inner Boudicca and say: “On your way, Barnier.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The Met Office says parts of northern England and Scotland will dip below freezing overnight.And forecasters have warned a plume of arctic air over the US and Canada is set to sweep in over the Atlantic and hit the UK this weekend.It will spark freezing temperatures and front next week.The cold snap follows days of balmy C temperatures and glorious sunshine earlier this week.A Met Office spokesperson told The Sun: Temperatures have been above average for quite a few places across the UK for the last couple of days, it’s been quite mild.But actually we’re seeing a cold front move its way south east across the country today.We’ve got cooler air filtering in from the North West and that cooler air will be with us as we look into the beginning of next week.News of the freeze comes after Brits basked in balmy C sunshine yesterday during an extremely warm October.But northern regions will be the first to feel the cold sweep in as clear skies could even mean frosts and fog tonight.Further south, therell be more cloud and some showers, but thankfully no snow is on the horizon any time soon.The Met Office spokesperson added: As we go through the next few days there will be some chilly nights in store and some patches of frost around overnight wherever the skies are clear.Tonight it’s really going to be across the northern half of the UK that we’ll be looking at where could be a risk of some frost, but then over the next few days they could really pop up anywhere where skies are clear because everyone will be in that cooler air.Through next week, it looks like we’re going to have a North West South East split.It will often be cloudier across the North West with some stronger winds and probably some spells of rain at times, whereas further South East it will generally be drier and brighter with some sunshine.Today there will be patchy rain in the south but it should be mostly sunny where, with temperatures generally in the mid-teens around the country.

story: Since the image was captures sales of the royal-colour stationary have skyrocketed.Australian outfit Officeworks said sales increased  per cent overnight, and the suddenly popular item has since sold out.A spokeswoman told the Daily Mail: Her unlikely accessory has sent stationery lovers into a frenzy, with the purple folder having almost sold out across Officeworks stores nationwide.This isnt the first time companies have sought to capitalise on the royals style.In September The Sun reported supermarkets including Tesco and Asda appeared to have launched dupes of Kate Middleton and Meghan Markle’s designer outfits for dirt cheap prices.And way back in  Burberry sold out of a brown trenchcoat modelled by Middleton.In a Facebook post Officeworks took full advantage of the unexpected latest royal plug.The brand wrote: Every royal celebrity style icon needs trusty document storage.Make like Meghan Markle by picking up one of our folders in a range of on-trend colours.The folder was described in a release as the latest must have accessory to conceal a babybump.Not everyone was impressed with the companys selling techniques.One wrote: Officeworks trying to fly on Meghans coat tails.Not a good look for them. How utterly ridiculous.Another branded the company opportunists.

title: brexit deal latest theresa may confronts eu leaders
story: The news was announced as Theresa May jetted in to Brussels to confront EU leaders in a desperate bid to move Brexit talks forward and strike a deal.French officials published a paper stating that in a No Deal scenario, British visitors to France would in principle need a visa to enter the country, and would be considered illegal immigrantsthey failed to apply for one.The document also revealed that French ministers are planning to implement new border checks the day after Brexitthe two sides fail to agree a deal.Its the first time a major European country has publicly announced plans for how it would cope with a No Deal outcome.Crunch talks in Brussels today come as top Eurocrats have suggested keeping Britain tied to the EU for an extra year.Michel Barnier, the chief European negotiator, is planning to offer Mrs May a -month extension to the post-Brexit transition period.He claims it could help the PM solve the Irish border dilemma by giving her more time to thrash out a permanent solution.But it would enrage Brexiteer MPs - because the UK would effectively remain a member of the EU until the end of .Mrs May travelled to Brussels today for a European Council summit involving all  EU leaders.She will deliver a half-hour speech to them before dinner tonight - but will then leave the room so the remaining  can discuss Brexit without her.The PM will also hold separate meetings with Donald Tusk, Jean-Claude Juncker and Irish PM Leo Varadkar.On a crucial day in the Brexit process:The EU meeting which starts today was previously earmarked as the moment when leaders would sign off an a withdrawal agreement.But talks broke down over the weekend after the EU insisted on a border backstop which could carve off Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK.Mrs May told a Cabinet meeting yesterday that she wont accept any deal which which breaks up the Union - or which keeps Britain tied to the EU customs union permanently.And speaking to MPs in the Commons today, the PM said: We continue to work for a good deal with the European Union - a deal that delivers on the Brexit vote but also a deal that protects jobs and livelihoods and crucially that protects the precious Union of the United Kingdom.We will not accept any proposals which would effectively break up the United Kingdom.She accused Jeremy Corbyn of preparing to betray voters by laying the ground for a second referendum on Brexit.Mrs May also rejected the Labour leaders claim that her Chequers proposals are dead after she failed to mention them by name in two recent speeches.Scottish Tory Adam Tomkins, a former law professor, today warned the PM that creating a border in the Irish Sea would lead to a crisis.He wrote in the Financial Times: Ruth Davidson, the leader of the Scottish Conservatives, and David Mundell, the Scottish Secretary, have made it clear to Mrs May that they would resign were Brexit to result in dferent deals for each of the UK’s constituent nations.These are not idle threats made in the heat of the moment - Scottish Tories are unionists first and Conservatives second.But Simon Coveney, Irelands deputy PM, insisted Mrs May must offer new proposals for the Irish border.He said thatthe two sides dont make progress this week, a proposed summit expected to take place in November could be scrapped.Mr Coveney told the BBC: There wont be a commitment to a new summit unless there is a signal from the negotiating teams that there is something to sign off on.What we dont want to do is create drama around the build-up to a new summit date and not actually have something to sign off on.Michael Gove suggested that a deal might not be signed until December - just three months before we officially quit the EU.He told a Commons committee: It might be the case - we’ve seen how European negotiations work - that progress is made at October council, progress is made at the November council, and it is even as late as the December council before a deal is done.Obviously, everyone wants the deal to be done earlier.Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt claimed one of the biggest threats to Brexit is Tory MPs like Boris Johnson who refuse to back Mrs Mays approach.He told the Daily Mail: Boris is a backbencher so he is free to say exactly as he thinks.But what I would say to Boris is be careful because there is a real danger thatall of us Conservative MPs do not stand behind the Prime Minister at a moment like this, the danger is that Brexit will be derailed altogether.I am sure that this is last thing Boris wants.The pro-EU veterans made a direct appeal to politicians across the EU, asking them to back calls for a second referendum.They wrote a joint opinion piece which appeared today in a number of European newspapers.The trio said: Our domestic debate is far from over and, even at this late hour, many of us are continuing to make the case that the British public need to make the final decision once we are in possession of all the relevant facts.So we ask our European partners to be ready to give us the space and time,necessary, to make such a final decision.They accused Brexiteers of being cynical pessimists who want to get a flimsy exit deal that they would later tear up in order to impose deregulation and tax cuts.The ex-PM and two former deputies have been blasted by Brexit-backing MPs who say they are undermining Britains negotiating position.

title: brits set for 230 a year pension boost and more money in your pocket as inflation drops
story: Pensioners will see a boost of almost £ a week from next April, and hard-working families will start to feel an ease to the cost of living squeeze.Inflation fell to . per cent from . per cent last month, as food and drink cost less.It means hard-up Brits will have more money in their pockets as they gear up for Christmas shopping.Mike Hardie, head of inflation at the ONS, said: Food was the main downward pull on inflation as last years September price rises failed to reappear, while ferry prices dropped after their surprisingly high summer peak.However, it wasnt all one-way traffic with energy suppliers pushing up their prices.And yesterday wages were shown to be rising by the fastest pace in nearly a decade - which will mean a boost for those on the state pension.This months figures are used to set public sector pensions for next April.Thanks to the triple lock, Brits will see a boost depending on which is higher - inflation, earnings or . per cent.Earnings for May - July were . per cent - which means the state pension will get boosted by this much next April.It works out at a £. a week, or £ a year for those on the full new state pension who will next year get £..And those on the old basic state pension will get a boost from £. per week, to £..Steve Webb, Director of Policy at Royal London said today: Whilst the rates of working age benefits have been squeezed for many years, pensioners look set to enjoy another above-inflation increase.Those receiving the full rate of the new state pension should get an extra £. per week or just over £ per year”.But the benefits freeze is set to continue to squeeze  million families, experts also warned today.New analysis by the Resolution Foundation finds that the four-year freeze in working age benefits – including Child Benefit, Tax Credits, Universal Credit, JSA, ESA and Housing Benefit – will save £.bn annually by next year, with £.bn of those savings coming from next year’s freeze alone.That means that this years freeze alone will make families around £ a year worse off.The benefit freeze has been in place since April , and is about to go into its fourth year.Adam Corlett, Senior Economic Analyst at the Resolution Foundation, said: “The Chancellor should prevent this hit to low-income families by cancelling the benefit freeze in his Budget later this month.”

title: rich kids mexico instagram private jet
story: Materialism is celebrated in all its glory with posts showing all the trappings of wealth and privilege such as private jets, super-cars, designer clothes and jewellery.They have drawn inspiration from the children of Russias oligarchs and billionaires who set up the “Rich Russian Kids” page on Instagram to show off their jet-set lestyles. Called “Rich Kids of Mexico”, this version has a way to go to catch up on their rivals so far boasting only , followers compared to the Russian pages one million. The images it features contrast starkly with the realities of le in Mexico where corruption and organised crime fuels intense poverty. According to the World Bank,  percent of the country’s population is poor - living on less than £. per day - with half of all children growing up impoverished.But those who are obscenely wealthy do not let this harsh reality of le for many in Mexico stop them from flaunting their wealth. One photo shows Sofia Castro, stepdaughter of the Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto, walking around New York in a Dolce  Gabbana suit. Another picture shows seven young men putting their hands together to show off their designer watches, with the caption: Squad goals.In one photograph of a large pile of banknotes comes with the words: This is how we roll! Unsurprisingly, foreign travel is also a common theme with holiday snaps of exotic locations or upscale areas of western European cities.Then there are photographs showing bottles of Champagne, signying the party lestyle enjoyed by those who don’t have to work to keep a roof over their heads.

title: entrepreneur rich pleads poverty speeding ban
story: Mitchell Stuart, , was caught by police doing almost twice the speed limit in his brand new Porsche  near a primary school.Stuart, who lives on Sandbanks, holidays on chartered yachts and feeds his pet dog steak, already had six points on his licence and faced being banned.He hired, at signicant cost, a top London barrister who told a court that his clients media business was in trouble and he was £, in arrears.Magistrates ignored Stuarts pleas and banned him for  days.Afterwards, Stuart sprinted out of court towards his fathers BMW car with his suit jacket covering his head to avoid photographers.Stuart, who runs social media company Inferno Media in Bournemouth, Dorset, was caught by a police officer doing speed checks near Lilliput Church of England Infant School.He was doing mph in a mph road shortly before pm on June .He was pulled over and immediately accepted he was driving too fast, telling PC Kier Dagnall: I dont know what Im thinking.At Poole Magistrates Court Stuart claimed he was running late for a meeting that would help his business survive.He claimed his business could collapse and he would be forced to declare bankruptcyhe was disqualied him from driving.But the magistrates were not told that six months ago Stuart gave an interview to thenewspaper boasting about earning a five-figure sum each month, owning two homes and taking off two weeks every month to travel the world.But barrister Archangelo Power, who specialises in serious crime including murder and armed robbery, told magistrates that client was in fact struggling financially.Mr Power said Stuart was given the Porsche as a present by his father but has since sold it.He said: He was not speeding for sheer enjoyment. He was late for a meeting. His business is in heavy arrears of some £,.This is a young man of previous good character who is also a school governor and has done his level best to work since he was .He is one of those start-up child prodigies.Mr Power claimed Stuart had taken on a second job in September with Com, doing social media for the communications company, as a result of his business troubles and his contract would be terminatedhe was disqualied.He also employs five people at his business, which Mr Power argued the loss of their jobs constituted exceptional hardship.But magistrate Martin Arthur lambasted Stuart for his actions.Mr Arthur said: It was a brand new Porsche. He is  years old. He is £, in arrears. That car probably cost more than £,. Its probably that sort of thing thats causing the business problems.He cannot drive in this manner through this conurbation, or any conurbation, and not have an accident and maybe kill someone.He told Stuart: We feel you need a short, sharp shock.Your company isnt going to fail because you were speeding. If its going to fail, its going to fail.The magistrates banned Stuart from driving for  days and ordered him to pay £ fine, £ victim surcharge and £ costs.In thearticle titled Money - How I spend It, Stuart claimed to have bought the Porsche himself, rather than it being a gt from his dad.Stuart said he started his business from scratch aged , selling advertising space on social media sites likes Facebook.He talked about preferring to travel by private jet and having been to  dferent places in the last year.He boasted of drumming up £, in business by meeting other CEOs while globetrotting.He said he had recently bought himself a £, jet ski as well as the Porsche.He also said he spends £ to £ a month on his Springer Spaniel dog Charlie, buying her a steak when they walk to the local pub.As well as his media company, Stuart said in the article that he has a six-figure sum invested in cryptocurrencies and two buy-to-let properties which pay for his mortgage on his three-bedroom Sandbanks flat.

title: 180000 brits are owed 5000 each after having their benefits underpaid by bungling officials
story: The Government will pay an average of £, to , disabled or ill claimants who were short-changed for years.The Department for Work and Pensions announced it faces a bill of nearly £billion for the blunder - three times as much as previously thought.It is the latest embarrassment for the department which is already under fire over the rollout of Universal Credit.Earlier this year, the DWP admitted it had underpaid thousands of claimants of Employment Support Allowance, which is intended for those too ill to work.Officials claimed , people were affected, with a total estimated cost of £million.But today they published an update which shows the numbers involved are much higher than previously thought.A total of , claimants are owed an average of £, each, with some due to be paid as much as £,.The overall bill to the taxpayer will be £million, most of which will be paid out over the next two years.Just  per cent of those affected have been paid the benefits they are owed.Civil servants are in the process of contacting the other , claimants and hope to be finished by next April.They are prioritising the most serious cases including those of people who are now terminally ill.Labour MP Neil Coyle blasted: Another criminal let-down of thousands of disabled people by a callous Government and a chaotic DWP.A spokesman for the DWP said: “Anyone affected by this historic error will receive all of the money they are entitled to.That is why we have created a dedicated team of over  staff to examine cases, and have paid back around £million so far.“We have worked with charities and other disability organisations to make sure that we are providing the right support to all affected claimants and are hiring and allocating more staff to do that.”

title: stomach churning moment animal lover lets her pet rat stick its head in her mouth and clean her teeth
story: The -second video shows the youngster standing still while the rat repeatedly pokes its head into a mouth held wide open.It reaches in, and seems to nibble on little bits of food, prized from between the woman’s teeth.The rat ferrets around several times, repeatedly entering up to its neck.The filmer then closes her mouth, and blows a kiss at the rodent.She then closes the animal’s cage.The video description reads: The video is of me and my pet rat, Colby. Our bond is strong and I trust him. He likes to eat food from my mouth, he will also groom and clean my teeth.A related thread on Reddit suggests the practice isn’t all that uncommon.There’s even a word for it: rodentistry.“Its pretty common, from what I understand. Mostly with female rats though.... None of my boys do it, but  of the  girls do,” one commenter wrote.The discussion is opened by a rat owner saying their rodent had started grooming and cleaning their teeth, and would “quite happily attempt to get right to the back of your mouth”.Cue the barrage of strange responses, including one owner who says their pet had “got this weird thing where he shoves his whole head in my mouth and expects me to close my lips around his head! Hes an oddball.”“Oh yes!” said another, “Yolandi loves to clean my teeth and inside my nose. I let her! Shes just grooming her mama. Ive opened my mouth for Pam to seeshe would, but it scared her so much she squeaked and froze up.The British Dental Association did not endorse the practice.A spokeswoman said: “To prevent gum disease and tooth decay, there is no substitute for brushing your teeth twice a day for at least two minutes with a fluoride toothpaste, including last thing at night.”The video, posted on YouTube, has received over  views.

title: london paddington rail delays major disruptions
story: All Great Western Railwaytrains between Paddington and Slough are expected to be suspended until at least midday today after overhead cables were damaged.Engineers have been working for hours to repair the damage, said to have been caused by a Hitachi test train operating between London and Bristol.Travellers have since taken to social media to share their frustrations as services were suspended until at least pm today and the Heathrow Express cancelled.One wrote on Twitter: When you get up at : to catch the early train to London and get to the station to be told Paddington Station is closed! #wednesdaymorning #tired #backtotheofficeAnother added: Probably the worst day ive had this year. Never ever trusting GWR, TfL Rail and Paddington Station again in my le.Some , people travel through Paddington daily, making it one of the busiest stations in London.Transport for London tweeted this morning: Due to damage to the overhead electrical wires there is no service on TfL Rail btw Paddington and Heathrow.Ticket acceptance is in place on local buses and London Underground. We are working closely with Network Rail to restore services as quickly as possible.Network Rail said its engineers are attempting to fix  metres of damaged electric power cables near Ealing after the outage.National Rail added: Yesterday evening the overhead electric wires near Ealing Broadway were severely damaged. As a result of this, trains are unable to run to and from London Paddington.Network Rail are working to recover all the stranded trains and to recty the damage to the overhead electric wires.Network Rail expect to reopen  of the  lines from midday.However trains will remain disrupted until the end of the day.Rail replacement buses are operating between London Paddington and Heathrow Airport.GWR said trains were stranded on the line between Paddington and Reading, adding: Owing to the extent of the damage, no trains are expected to be able to operate between London Paddington and Hayes  Harlington in either direction for much of Wednesday.As a result, GWR, TfL Rail and Heathrow Express will not be operating a train service between London Paddington, Hayes  Harlington or Slough until such time as repairs have been completed.Officials have warned most trains will start and terminate at Reading, with a reduced train service operating between Reading and Slough.National Rail has told those travelling to London from beyond Reading to not go to Paddington but instead travel straight to either London Waterloo, London Marylebone or London Euston.A Hitachi spokesman said: After years of successful testing on the route, we are taking today very seriously, a full and thorough investigation is taking place to identy the cause.British Transport Police confirmed they were assisting Network Rail with the overhead line issue.

title: meghan markle prince harry dubbo australian tour
story: The expectant parents were greeted with hugs and flowers as they arrived in the city of Dubbo just days after announcing they were expecting their first child in spring next year. The couple seemed thrilled to meet kids in the regional town, praised by locals as they showed off their parenting instincts.Farm family member Emily Carroll, , watched as Meghan played with her -month-old Ruby Carroll, later saying: They’re both great with kids.She added Meghan admitted she was running on adrenaline as the couple fit in  engagements in  days.Five-year-old Luke Vincent also got up close and personal with the couple, with the adorable tot telling Prince Harry, , he was his favourite person after Father Christmas as he pulled on the royals ginger beard.Little Luke tugged on Harrys beard, saying: I like beards because I like Father Christmas.The Buninyong Public School pupil was among the -strong welcoming party for the royal visit to the New South Wales city,  miles from Sydney.Harry and Meghan, , had to contend with heavy rain as the Prince spoke to Australias struggling farmers, telling them to ask for help.She stepped in to hold an umbrella over her husband who joked its all right, Ive got my we when the heavens opened.They also met with Royal Flying Doctor Service volunteers and unveiled a new plane to mark the services  years.Mum-to-be Meghan arrived wearing jeans by Aussie brand Outland, a shirt from Maison Kitsune,  Boots from J Crew and a jacket from her friend Serena Williams collection and necklace by Natalie Marie.During their day visit to Dubbo, the parents-to-be helped out on a local farm and met with farmers to discuss the drought which has struck the region.The royal couple headed straight from the airport to meet with flying doctors where they learnt about childbirth using a mannequin.They also cut a cake to celebrate  years of the service and unveiled a new plane.They then headed to a picnic and barbecue at a park for members of the public where Meghan even baked a banana bread to take with her.She reportedly made the treat - including the special ingredient ginger - last night in the kitchen at Admiralty House.Later Meghan met with schoolgirls who are part of the Girls’ Academy which supports those from Aboriginal  Torres Strait Islanders backgrounds.Their motto is Develop a Girl, Change a community and Meghan said: “You’re speaking my language.Pregnant Meghan, who is understood to have already had her -week scan, glowed as she met with school children and was handed flowers from excited students.The Duke of Sussex said yesterday he and his we could not think of a better place to announce the upcoming baby than Australia.Sources have since said the future dad is happier than he has ever been after the news his we Meghan was pregnant.A source added: “It is something he has wanted for a long time, and he couldn’t be happier. He is so protective of her.”Kensington Palace revealed that their first child is due next spring, with Meghan saying they are both excited about parenthood.As the couples visit to Dubbo continued, Harry and Meghan met a hero medic who pulled three survivors from a helicopter crash in Afghanistan.Ex-soldier Marcus Wilson, who was awarded Australias Bravery Medal for his actions, will be taking part in the Invictus Games in the sailing event.Now manager of the Royal Flying Doctor Service in Broken Hill, New South Wales, the -year-old was at Nato HQ in Kabul in October  when a helicopter crashed near where he was standing.Medically discharged from the army because of a spinal injury, and traumatised by the helicopter crash, Mr Wilson found himself at a loss after leaving Afghanistan.Then he watched the Invictus Games in Toronto, and volunteered for the Sydney games.He said: I have seen how much it has impacted not just on me, but other team members and their families.The couple even had to contend with flies as heroic Prince Harry stepped in to swat them away from one woman.The Duke of Sussex lunged into action to flick away the critters as Meghan laughed by his side.Meghan was forced to hold a brolly over hubby Harry as a downpour drenched their Oz farm visit.The Duchess of Sussex smiled at him as he delivered a speech in the rain on Wednesday morning in a drought hit farm that had been praying for rain.The Prince told the cheering crowd: Thank you for welcoming me and my we so warmly.He laughed and stumbled over his words as the showers got heavier as he spoke, soaking his blue shirt.October  Harry and Meghan spent their first day in Sydney getting close to wildle, including meeting two namesake joeys, and were greeted by hundreds of well-wishers outside the famous Opera House after watching an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander modern dance company.The duchess, wearing an ivory Karen Gee dress with earrings and a bracelet which belonged to the dukes mother, Diana, said Our first baby gt! when the Governor General handed her the kangaroo.After being congratulated on their baby news Meghan replied: Thank you so much. We are very excited.

title: the remarkable legacy of microsofts paul allen
story: Yes, there were the fabulous properties and outsize boats.But there were also investments in science, the arts, community, sport and exploration.It was he who funded ious searches for the lost wrecks of the Second World War.Allens project discovered the resting place of the USS Indianapolis, which delivered the atomic bomb, and also the Japanese warships Musashi, the heaviest armed ship in naval history.Along with the Titanic, these are some of the greatest, most painstaking, finds on our seabed.Butwrecks arent your thing, then try sport.Allen was a sports fan.A basketball lover, he bought the Portland Trail Blazers in  and never lost his affection for the team.

title: brexit summit kicks theresa mays
story: NewsBrexit summit kicks off in Theresa Mays moment of truth as UK admits deal may take until DECEMBERThe Prime Minister will hold crisis talks with EU chiefs Donald Tusk before addressing  fellow leaders before their dinnerShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editorDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsTheresa May is sweeping into Brussels for a moment of truth Brexit summit "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May is sweeping into Brussels for a moment of truth Brexit summit as the UK sensationally admits a deal may take until DECEMBER. The Prime Minister will hold crisis talks with EU chiefs Donald Tusk and Jean-Claude Juncker and Irish premier Leo Varadkar before addressing  fellow leaders before their dinner. She will beg them to break the deadlock over the Northern Irish border - and unlock a special summit to finalise a deal next month. But last night Mr Tusk demanded new facts before hell do that. And after days of EU chiefs pouring cold water on the plan, today Michael Gove admitted it may take until December.  The Environment Secretary told a House of Lords committee: We’ve seen how European negotiations work. It might be the case that progress is made at October [European] Council, progress is made at the November council, and it’s even as late as the December council before a deal is done. Obviously everyone would like a deal to be done earlier. [But]insufficient progress is there by November then the government will take stock, reflect, and the Prime Minister will decide at what point to say ‘this is our lead option’. Evena deal was struck on December - in Brussels it would still have to go to MPs and European parliaments for approval. By then No Deal plans would be well advanced.  Meanwhile there is fresh drama over Brexit, fresh splits in the Cabinet and fresh unrest in the Tory party:Jeremy Corbyn blasted Mrs May at PMQs for putting the Tory partys interests first, adding she is too weak and too ided to protect peoples jobs or our economy - or ensure there is no hard border in Northern Ireland. Britain faces paying almost all its poundbn orce bill in No Deal, the Chancellor warned the Cabinet. Philip Hammond reportedly said the nation would only save poundbn to poundbn due to legal liabilities. Today Mrs May refused to rule out having to hand over most of the sum. Liam Fox reportedly backed extending the transition period beyond December . The Brexiteer Trade Secretary is said to have made the comment at yesterdays Cabinet meeting, despite No saying it will not happen. Irish Foreign Minister Simon Coveney backed a transition extension too, saying: The EU side is willing to allow more time in the transition period to agree an alternative solution to the backstop. Michael Gove accused officials of tricking him into accepting the last deal in December, saying: “Fool me once, shame on you fool me twice, shame on me.”Philip Hammond slapped down Boris Johnson saying: What I would say to Boris is be careful because there is a real danger thatall of us Conservative MPs do not stand behind the Prime Minister at a moment like this, the danger is that Brexit will be derailed altogether. The head of the Department of Health admitted medicine shortage fears keep him awake at night. The US confirmed Brexit trade deal talks will begin in MONTHS - igniting fresh fears of an influx of chlorine chicken. Tony Blair and Nick Clegg joined forces with an article urging EU leaders to give Britain the space and time for a second referendum.The Prime Minister will address  EU leaders chiefs tonight in Brussels before they tuck into dinner without her.  Mrs May is expected to urge her counterparts to ease their position over the Northern Ireland frontier, which is the biggest block to striking a deal. Negotiators reached stalemate over proposals for preventing a hard border with the Republic - the UK’s only land frontier with the EU -no deal can be agreed. EU chiefs want a “backstop” where Northern Ireland remains in the customs union, which would split it from the rest of the UK. The PM cannot back the move because the Democratic Unionist Party - on whose votes she relies - is bitterly opposed. Instead, Mrs May has said the whole UK could effectively stay in a temporary customs union - but refused to set an end date. That enrages Brexiteers who fear Britain would be banned from signing trade deals with other countries, forced to pump cash into the Brussels budget and have no say over new rules.  Irish deputy prime minister Simon Coveney told the BBC: “A lot of work has happened over the last two weeks that have actually found ways of closing gaps and getting agreement. But there are a small number of remaining issues. They are signicant issues, so we shouldn’t downplay them, that need to be resolved.” It had been hoped agreement could be reached, paving the way for a rubber-stamping summit next month. But Mr Coveney said: “I think what’s more likely is that dates will be suggested, but that there won’t be a commitment to a new summit unless there is a signal from the negotiating teams that there is something to sign off on. And I think that’s sensible. What we don’t want to do is create drama around the build-up to a new summit date and not actually have something to sign off on. Both sides want to get a deal done here, and I think we need... to allow the negotiating teams to set the pace with a view to making recommendations, hopefully by mid-November, that a new summit is necessary to sign off on a final deal.”

title: guide tricking bnp ukip supporters
story: NewsGuide to tricking BNP and Ukip supporters into voting Green condemned by Theresa May at PMQsSolihull MP Julian Knight said theres no place for "pandering to racism" - and the Prime Minister agreedShareCommentsByJames RodgerMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video guide-tricking-bnp-supporters-voting-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A Councillors guide to tricking BNP supporters into voting for the Green Party has been strongly condemned by Theresa May . The Green Party gave its activists hints about how to win votes from BNP supporters, the Birmingham Mail revealed today.They were told to encourage BNP supporters to go to the polling station, in the hope they would end up picking the Green candidate. The advice was contained in a detailed document called “How to Win an Election”, written by Chris Williams, the party’s Regional Manager for Elections and a councillor in Solihull. In a section on canvassing, the document invited activists to imagine they are in a seat where the Greens were challenging Labour, and explained how to responda voter said they backed the BNP or UKIP.  The document said: “If they say BNP or UKIP, then do not tell them that there is no BNP or UKIP candidatebutthey appear to be very anti-Labour, then we do want them to go to the polling station. “When they get there, they will see no BNP or UKIP candidate and so may vote Green instead.” Instead, activists were told to say: “Do you know you have  Labour Councillors in this area at the moment, which means they have the monopoly  [Candidate] has been working all year round - you have probably seen the newsletters – and so you may wish to consider voting for him in order to keep Labour out. It’s a two-horse race around here between Labour and [candidate].”The Green Party are the official opposition in Solihull, with  councillors. Nationwide they have one MP and are led by Sian Berry and Jonathan Bartley. It was raised at Prime Ministers Questions today, by Tory Solihull MP Julian Knight. He asked Mrs May: Not long ago, we had the horror of three pig’s heads being left outside a Muslim community centre in Solihull. Then the EDL thugs came to my proud and multicultural town and we turned our backs on them. In this light, will the PM join me in condemning utterly the actions of a Solihull Green Councillor, as reported in the Birmingham Mail, who has written a guide on how to attract and trick BNP voters  He added: There is no place for pandering to racism in my town or in our politics.  Mrs May replied: I absolutely agree with him. There is no place in our society for pandering to racism of any sort. And we should send a very clear message of that from the whole of this house. The BNP currently has no elected representatives anywhere, though at one time it had more than  council seats nationwide. It is a party which believes in putting “British” people and also argues that only ethnic white Europeans can be British.A Green Party spokesperson said: “The document referred to is a now old guide to conversations on the doorsteps where we will encounter constituents from all political persuasions, who have voted in a iety of ways over the course of their voting lives.“The Green Party will always listen to voters on the doorstep and will not make judgements about them based on their voting intentions past or present. “We know that many people feel frustrated and disenfranchised by mainstream politics and have looked for an alternative.“The Green Party offers a solution of hope, not hate, and we are proud to have taken seats from UKIP, erased the BNP in Solihull and to offer an anti establishment alternative that can challenge the politics of hate.“Only by winning votes from the disenfranchised and changing the narrative can we defeat the far right, which the Green Party is helping to do.”

title: its time applaud theresa mays
story: NewsopinionIts time to applaud Theresa Mays incredible lack of achievementNever in the field of human endeavour has one person done so little for so longShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  OCT Newsopinion"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIn  Winston Churchill said British airmen undaunted by odds, unwearied in their constant challenge and mortal danger were turning the tide of the war. Never has so much been owed by so many to so few, he said. Today, you could say much the same of Theresa May, although shes not doing barrel rolls in a Spitfire. Churchill was praising The Few who kept the Nazis at bay in the Battle of Britain, just long enough that the country could regroup and fight on for another  years.Theresa has spent two years winging it. She has dodged incoming fire from her own side, skirmished with the enemy across the Channel, fought a general election and all while faced with an hopeless and daunting task shamefully abandoned by the previous Prime Minister. Brexit is not just unlikely, its impossible. The country voted for the entire United Kingdom to leave the European Union, and Northern Ireland cannot leave without the United Kingdom ceasing to exist. Either Northern Ireland remains, which would makes the vote invalid, or the UK breaks up, which makes it moot.Most people who faced that ever-decreasing circle of hell for two years would go completely mad. We should be proud, as a nation, that the only manestation of our leaders insanity is limited to her elbows. And consider the alternatives - Andrea Im a mother Leadsom, Michael do you like my flesh suit Gove, or Boris woof woof, fruity, I say, what  Johnson.Andrea would have wheeled screaming into the sea  months ago. Gove would have begun trade talks with the lizards from V, and Johnson would have said Bwah, lets just walk awaaaaaaaaaaaaay as he stomped off the White Clfs of Dover onto a bridge that wasnt there and splatted onto the rocks below, taking the British economy with him. Every car manufacturer, farmer, exporter, importer, engineering firm and financial business is terried of the Boris Plan, which is an optimistic name for something all about not having a plan.If Boris was PM, Project Fear would have become reality two years ago. Hed be fine, and the rest of us would be f***ed.  Theresa had the good sense to trigger Article , which would kick the can down the road for two solid years. Two years in which the nation had mild mental depression, rather than a great financial one. Two years in which our economy had uncertainty as opposed to disaster.And for most of it, Theresa gave the job of negotiations to an egotistical idiot incapable of compromise or comprehension. Asking David Davis to extract us from the EU was like asking Edd the Duck to do quadratic equations: destined for failure.Were lucky to have had his ineptitude working in the nations best interests for as long as we did before he flounced off to be inept on the backbenches. Throughout all this Theresa has survived coup attempts, naked politicking, and insubordination. She has actually BENEFITTED from the lack of discipline within her own party, because the plotters are cannibalising each other while shes left to get on with it. And what shes getting on with is nothing whatsoever. That itself is a feat - Prime Ministers are surrounded by advisors, deal-makers, lobbyists, donors, editors, magnates and other nations all pushing her to make decisions. To achieve zero in the face of all the opportunity to do more is simply remarkable. Theresa promised social justice, and failed to manest it. She promised money for the NHS, parity for the mentally ill, schools, jobs, help, funding. Not one of them has appeared, and nor are they likely to. The nation still voted her back in. And we took her lessons to heart - we didnt make much of a decision at all, producing a hung parliament and a deal with the Democratic Ulster Unionists which actually makes the Northern Ireland problem MORE COMPLICATED.By straining ever sinew, Theresa has managed to do nothing at all. For a nation that propelled itself to a clf edge in a highly-emotional state, the fact were still standing on it is almost progress. Yes, prices are up, wages are stagnating, Esther McVeys still a thing and nothing is any better. But it might be worth noting that most things are NOT magnicently worse, and whatever is can be attributed to a hangover from previous years of Tory rule.John Major did not outlast the Eurosceptics. David Cameron did not renegotiate the deal with the EU. Even Margaret Thatcher could not have survived two solid years of blatant leadership manoeuvres.Teflon Theresa has, somehow. Despite Windrush, Grenfell, rising homelessness and a never-ending crisis in AE. Im not arguing shes clever, or shed have figured out the only way out of this mess was to call a general election and ensure one side campaigned for Remain. And Im not arguing shes stupid, or she would have been pressured by civil servants, friends and enemies to do something really bad by now.What Theresa May has by the bucketload is staying power, coupled with a martyr complex which must mean that she enjoys impossible odds, constant undermining, and the mortal danger that extreme stress brings any of us, never mind diabetics.If you voted Leave, you may resent Theresa for not producing it. You should be glad she delayed a disastrous Brexit, and spent two years making it look like your dream of unicorns was deliverable rather than deranged. Andyou voted Remain, you may resent her for insisting on doing a harmful thing that cannot be done properly anyway. You should be glad she gave the country two years to notice it. In a time of immense political turmoil, here and abroad, Theresa has made instability a constant. Weve had two years of no disaster, and all because never before in the field of human endeavour has one person done so little for so long.Everyone who loathes her, put down your politics. Give around of applause for the Prime Minister fighting a one-woman Battle of Britain, and who in doing so has bought us the most important thing of all - time.Now, what are you going to do with it

story: NewsopinionPMQs was an off day as Jeremy Corbyn missed an open goal with enfeebled Theresa MayThis wasnt one of Corbyns better performances and he missed an open goal when Theresa May is enfeebled, writes Kevin MaguireShareCommentsByKevin MaguireAssociate editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsopinionthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video associate-editor-kevin-maguire-reacts-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJeremy Corbyn is right - Theresa May is too weak at the head of a ided Government to fight Britains corner in Europe and must stop putting the Conservative Partys interests first. title: tory mp denies trying frighten
story: NewsTory MP denies trying to frighten voters into calling CRIMESTOPPERS on his opponentsEXCLUSIVE: William Wraggs flyer has been branded "cheap and nasty" by Vince CableShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsMr Wragg says nobody has, as yet, reported him to Crimestoppers"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Tory MP has denied trying to ‘frighten’ voters out of talking to rival candidates, after he sent out leaflets warning them to chain their doors and call Crimestoppersthey get an unexpected caller. William Wragg published the leaflet, which features ‘red, yellow and green’ warnings. He denied the graphic was intended to represent his Labour, Lib Dem and Green rivals in his Greater Manchester constituency of Hazel Grove. The flyer reads: “Beware doorstep callers. If you get an unexpected caller, don’t just open the door”, before suggesting residents “put on your door chain or door bar before opening the door.” Below the advice, it lists the phone number for Crimestoppers.  The leaflet features a large picture of Mr Wragg. And the reverse, designed to be placed in a window warning away cold callers, also includes Mr Wragg’s name in large letters. Lib Dem leader Sir Vince Cable said: “This is cheap and nasty. It discourages people from talking to candidates. “The Conservatives are trying to frighten people so they don’t engage with other politicians. They want to shut up opposition rather than debate.” Mr Wragg said the leaflet had been ‘spurred’ by an increase in rogue trader activity in his area of Stockport and denied it was intended particularly to deter political canvassers.  He insisted: “The traffic lights being the party colours, and so forth, wasn’t my intention… It certainly wasn’t intended to stop canvassers from other parties.” Certainly not that in mind at all. It’s out of the motivation that having spoken with Greater Manchester Police, I engaged with them and said this is what I think I can do from me. It’s certainly not to deter canvassers, candidates or anybody .
